I spotted a bug whereby when I reset the enabled flag on an new genome's 
connection I also reset it on the parent! This most likely had a 
detrimental effect on searching and in fact my update of yesterday's 
graph indicates that this might have been the case:

http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/enablebitgraph2.png

The two experimetents (with and without the enable bit) are now much 
more in-line with each other, whereas enablebitgraph.png showed slightly 
better results without the enable bit. I had put this difference down to 
not avergaing over enough runs, which could still be the case, but the 
new graph does show four very well matched lines.

Colin.



Colin Green wrote:

>Maybe some of you will find this of interest...
>
>As a precursor to my phased searching work I thought about simplfying 
>the NEAT genome ever so slightly by eliminating the 'enable' flag on a 
>connection gene. I just ran a experiment using my new OCR code and, 
>although it's not the most thorough scientific analysis it does seem to 
>hint that the enable bit isn't all that beneficial.
>
>I ran the same search 10 times, 5 with the enable bit, 5 without. Each 
>run was 1000 generations. I have produced a graph that shows the average 
>of the runs here:
>
>http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/enablebitgraph.png
>
>
>Colin
>
>  
>
